New Records: The six homers allowed by the Dodgers were the most the team has ever allowed in a playoff game in franchise history.
Key Match Events: The San Diego Padres hit a total of six homers in their 10-2 blowout victory over the Dodgers in Game 2 of the NLDS.
Yu Darvish allowed just one run on three hits in seven strong innings with three strikeouts.
Fernando Tatis Jr. hit two home runs.
David Peralta hit a two-run homer in the top of the second inning.
Rookie Jackson Merrill, Xander Bogaerts, and catcher Kyle Higashioka each hit one home run.
Max Muncy hit a home run with two outs in the bottom of the ninth.
Jurickson Profar robbed Mookie Betts from a game-tying home run in the first inning.
Tommy Edman hit a line drive to Luis Arraez at first base that turned into an easy inning-ending double play.
Pre-Game Insights: The Padres knew they had to recapture their identity for Game 2.
Yu Darvish's performance was anticipated to be crucial for the Padres.
Post-Match Reflections: Fernando Tatis Jr. commented on the Padres' aggressive mindset from the beginning.
Max Muncy expressed disappointment in the team's performance but remained hopeful.
Padres' manager Mike Shildt praised his team's resilience in a hostile environment.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Tensions ran high at Dodger Stadium during Game 2 of the National League Division Series.
The rivalry between the Los Angeles Dodgers and San Diego Padres has intensified over the last six years.
Fans threw baseballs onto the field during the bottom of the seventh inning, leading to a lengthy delay.
